Author: jl777c#5810
Content: CC contracts are native code running at full speed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: any language that can be compiled into a library can be used, but we are just getting started with making different language bindings and it wouldneed to interface to the c/c++ functions inside the komodod

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: my thinking is that blockchain coding is difficult and not something end users or casual programmers should be doing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: such can and have led to some very expensive errors

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <james> OK.  So it is c++

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <Rubinho> could you walk me thought how am I (the end user) going to use KMD in the system? is KMD like GAS for the platform?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even experienced blockchain devs make errors

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: C++ is the easiest, but any language that compiles would be able to be used

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [telegram] <J> Thanks for doing the heavy lifting, I don‚Äôt want to mess with that bullshit :P (re @Matterbridge_kmdbot: [discord] <jl777c> my thinking is that blockchain coding is difficult and not something end users or casual programmers should be doing)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: rust would likely not be too hard to interface to

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the CC contracts tend to be configurable, so the user can determine the settings of the rewards and not have to code it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course a full blockchain project creating their own dapp would need to still create their own dapp

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but on their own chain, there is no crazy txfee, congestion, etc
